sen.j: 天領（てんりょう）とは江戸幕府の直轄領のことを指す通称。
sen.e: Tenryo is a common name for territories under direct control of the Edo Shogunate.
Tenryo is commonly known as a name for territories that were under the direct control of the Edo Shogunate.
sen.cmt: 時制を修正致しました。
sen.e: Tenryo is commonly known as a name for territories that were under the direct control of the Edo Shogunate.

sen.j: 天領という用語は、明治初期に旧幕府直轄領が天皇の御料（直轄領）になったときに天領と呼ばれるようになったため、さかのぼって幕府時代のものも天領と呼ぶようになったもので、江戸時代に使われていた用語ではない。
sen.e: The term "tenryo" was not used in the Edo period; the term began to be used to define territories under control of the former Edo Shogunate when such territories became the Imperial property at the beginning of the Meiji era, and the territories under the Shogunate's control in the Edo period came to be also called "tenryo" retrospectively.

The term "tenryo" was not used in the Edo period; its use began when territories that were under the control of the former Edo Shogunate became the Imperial property at the beginning of the Meiji era, and retrospectively, territories that were under the Shogunate's control during the Edo period also came to be referred to as "tenryo."

sen.j: 幕府直轄の各領地には代官処がつくられ、郡代や代官・遠国奉行が支配した。
sen.e: Daikan-sho or Office of Local Governor was set up in each territory under direct control of the Shogunate, and such posts as gundai (intendant of a region), daikan (local governor), or ongoku-bugyo (the collective name of the magistrates placed at important areas directly controlled by the government in the Edo period) were assigned to control those territories.

Daikan-sho (Office of Local Governor) were established in each of the territories that were under the direct control of the Shogunate, and gundai (intendant of a region), daikan (local governor), or ongoku-bugyo (the collective name of the magistrates placed at important areas directly controlled by the government in the Edo period) governed those territories.
sen.cmt: 文を平易に致しました。

sen.j: 豊臣氏政権時代の徳川氏の蔵入地を基とし、関ヶ原の戦い、大坂の役などでの没収地を加えて、17世紀末には約400万石となった。
sen.e: The tenryo of the Tokugawa Shogunate started from the territories under direct control of the Tokugawa clan in the period of the Toyotomi clan's regime and went up to about 4 million goku at the end of the 17th century after including the confiscated territories following major battles including the Battle of Sekigahara and the Seizes of Osaka.

The tenryo started from the directly-controlled land of the Tokugawa clan during the period of the Toyotomi clan's regime, and with the addition of territories that were confiscated through such battles as the Battle of Sekigahara and the Seizes of Osaka, it was four million goku by the end of the 17th century.
sen.cmt: 言い回しを少し変え、平易に致しました。

sen.j: その年貢収入は幕府の財政基盤となり、大坂、長崎など重要な都市や佐渡金山などの鉱山も天領とされた。
sen.e: The land tax income served as the financial basis of the Shogunate, and major cities such as Osaka and Nagasaki and the mines such as the Sado Gold Mine were included into the tenryo.

sen.j: 甲斐国、飛騨国は一国まるごと天領となった。

sen.j: 江戸末期に老中首座となった水野忠邦は、天保の改革の一環として上知令（江戸城大阪城の十里四方を天領とする）を発令したため、周辺に領地を持つ大名から大きく非難された。
sen.e: Tadakuni MIZUNO, who became the head of Roju (senior councilors of the Tokugawa Shogunate) at the end of the Edo period, issued an Agechi-rei (confiscation command of territory), which intended to turn the area around the Edo Castle and Osaka Castle ten "ri" (one "ri" is about 3.927km) in radius from each castle, as part of the Tempo Reforms, and daimyo lords having territories around those castles severely criticized him.

As a part of the Tempo Reforms, Tadakuni MIZUNO, who became the head of Roju (senior councilors of the Tokugawa Shogunate) at the end of the Edo period, issued Agechi-rei (confiscation command of territory) to turn the area within a radius of 10 ri (one "ri" is about 3.927km) from the Edo and Osaka Castle into tenryo, and daimyo lords having territories around these castles criticized him severely.
